commit_list.message:
Cleaned up the header generation by moving them out to seperate methods.
Removed the usage of "<<EOF" and made those lines match the other lines so it's easier to read.
Added code to handle the sending of images. Works for either local images or URL images.
 * URL images just have the URL copied into the icon header, as the growl client deals with them.
 * Local images are read and transmitted in the request.
Local image sending is currently not working. The requests look sane and match the very few examples available, the growl client just doesn't use
them, for some currently unknown reason.

commit_list.message:
Tidied up the migrations.

   doesn't create a new string array each time
 * Formatted the migration parameters better so it's easier to scan through the
   columns

 * Converted the growing and wilt times to minutes instead of hours (just in
   case they ever decide to include quick crops, and to make things consistent
   with the other games that I plan to support which already have quick things)
 * Fix the profit value for one crop

commit_list.message:
Don't allow holidays to begin before and finish after an existing confirmed holiday.

 * Added a getDayDiv function that'll return the correct div and handles both Date objects and date strings. This is because
   the lookup is done in a few places and it's better to have it as a function that handles both cases.
 * Added a checkForConfirmed function that scans through the selected day divs and checks it any have a class of 'confirmed'.
   If so then it returns true, otherwise it'll return false if it finishes going through them all.
 * Used the checkForConfirmed function and if it returns true then set the dateField to 1 (so the next click is the end date),
   then sets the startDate and endDate to the clicked date.
 * Also disallow clicking of a day div that has a 'confirmed' class. This doesn't affect the dateField at all as maybe they
   slipped and caught a confirmed day but meant to click a normal day to set the end date, which they can then do.

commit_list.message:
Implemented a proper role system. Instead of listing controllers and actions that the user can access, have each controller
specify what role is required for the individual actions. This then requires no changes to the database if an action or
controller is added or removed.
The role system is implemented as a plugin so that you can just put "needs_role :user, :actions => [:new, :index]" and it'll
work just fine. A controller has public access unless a role has been specified. If at least one role is specified (you can
have multiple roles protecting different actions) then a valid login is required to access that controller and action, and a
role that matches the action is required. If no login is found then they're redirected to the login page (like before). If no
role is found then they're redirected to the home_path route.
The user authentication has also been moved into a plugin so that it can be used from within the role plugin. I could find an
easy way to keep it in the application.rb file and the sessions controller. No big deal as it was pretty easy to do, and it
makes the login process a bit neater.

commit_list.message:
Use the new fixed point math plugin in the models.

 * Added the fixed_point_number and _integer calls at the top of the model.
 * Removed the getter and setter methods as the plugin handles all of that.

Added a fixed point math plugin that adds a fixed_point_number method to the ActiveRecord models. This will cut down on all the getter and setter
methods that are currently in the models to do the fixed point math conversion.
Add rspec to the website. I thought I had done this before, but I guess not.
Remove some crud from the custom_environment initializer as it's not used any longer.
Update the controller tests to use ActionController::TestCase instead of Test::Unit::TestCase, as the home controller was failing (the other controller test have nothing in them, so...).
Don't test the contact form as it has currently been removed (planning to put it back in at a later date, hence the tests left in, just commented out).
Don't reset the session as it invalidates anything we put in it.

More rails 2.3.2 changes.

* No need to set the session key in the application controller.
 * Don't reset the session on login (both normal and openid) as this invalidates what is then put in it and it gets lost
   (this was a tough problem to sort out!)
 * Modified the environment.rb file to bring it up to date with the rails 2.3.2 default.
 * Moved the sessions store stuff out into an initializer file.
 * Updated the rails defaults initializer file. Not sure why I did as it's all JSON stuff and I don't really use JSON.
 * Removed some crud from the custom_environment initializer as they're not used any longer.
 * Added a migration to recreate the sessions tables as they appear to have changed a bit.
Remove the secret key from the protect_from_forgery call as it's not needed any longer.
Use normalize_identifier instead of normalize_url, as normalize_url is now deprecated.
Changed Test::Unit::TestCase to ActiveSupport::TestCase.
Update the open_id_authentication plugin to make it work with rails 2.3.
Update to rails 2.3.
Freeze the rails 2.3.2 gems.
Remove the rails 2.2.2 gems.
Removed the whole contact form and listed just an email address. Maybe it'll be put back later either as something that sends emails or something that sends messages internally.
Reformatted the html for the admin interface.

Do the cancel button stuff on the admin interface.

 * Changed some of the submit buttons from Update to Save.
 * Made the admin users edit form actually point to the admin users url, not the users url.
 * Added the admin user login destroy view file as it seems it was missing before.

Changed to the news display.

 * Made the news item pagination take a per_page parameter and use that.
 * Use the news item pagination for the home index page, only displaying 3 items.
 * Order the news items by descending id as well as posted_on date (so that two items posted on the same day appear in the correct order).
 * Reformatted the news views and removed a useless span tag.
 * Added overflow: hidden to the news-item div so that the news items are displayed correctly even if it's a one line item.

Make the cancel buttons work without using javascript.

 * Changed the cancle_button helper to be a submit button.
 * Added a before filter to the controllers to handle the cancel button.

* Make the food quantity check to make sure the name and quantity are on the same row (just incase...).
 * Use the correct submit name as it changed.
Added sidebars for all the sections to display the help links.
Don't override the controller in the foods and target_weights controllers.
Change exercise to exercises and targetweight to targetweights, to match with the other names.
Formatting cleanup.
Added the meals help section.
Merge branch 'master' into help
Actually link the 'Add Food' menu item to the new food route, instead of the foods index page.
Make the exercise menu item actually link to the exercuse section. How have I missed this so far?
Added the exercise help section.
Added the activities help section.
Use 'existing' instead of 'entered' in the question.
Added the foods help section.
Added another question/answer to the measurements help page.
Actually add the target weight help page.
Added the target weight help. Not too sure about the text for this. Might be revised later on.
Added the help page/images for the measurements section.
Expand the weights help a bit.
Set the font-size for the ol tag so that it matches the rest of the text.
Removed the ol tag from the reset so that it displays correctly. Currently it's only going to be used in the help section, so it's not a big deal if it doesn't look the same in all browsers.
Merge branch 'master' into help
Use the remove.gif image instead of delete.gif. Also renamed the input to remove to match the image.
Updated the images to put circles around the focus points. Removed weights-list.jpg as it's not used now.
Merge branch 'master' into help
Renamed delete.gif to remove.gif, and cross.gif to delete.gif, as they better describe what the images represent.
The start of a new help system. Currently only covering the weights section.
Removed the img definition as it's covered by the reset at the top. Added an img.help definition to put a bit of margin around the help images.
Remove the ul and li tags from the reset so that they can be used, and appear correctly, in the main content. Added padding: 0 to the menu ul so that the menu isplays correctly.
Should be updating the text in the strong tag, not wiping it out.
The inputs now have a span tag around them, meaning that an extra parent() call is needed to get to the form.
Updated the calendar tour image to show a more populated calendar.
Fiddled with the signup form. Moved some of the text to the bottom, reworded the OpenID part, stuck a fieldset around the form elements, and stuck format hints for the loginname and password.
Cast the params id to an integer before doing the find (just to be on the safe side).
Remove the unneeded exception handling.
Simplify the create action by using .build and .save! instead of .new and <<.
Moved the existing target weight check out to a before filter.
The final removal of unobtrusive javascript for deleting items.
And another round of removing obtrusive javascript. This time it's in the admin interface.

Pretty much the same as the previous commit removing the javascript confirmation and form creation/submission from the delete links and using the
new unobtrusive javascript method.

Make the measurements destroy links use unobtrusive javascript.

 * Added the javascript click event function to handle confirmation and form creation/submitting for all delete links.
 * Added a member route to the measurements resource so that the destroy action can be reached by a GET request.
 * Changed the measurement partial to just be a plain link to the measurements destroy action. The delete css class is what the javascript uses.
 * Added a before filter that gets the measurement (or sets an error and redirects) for the edit, update, and destroy actions.
 * Changed the edit, update, and destroy actions as they don't need to get the measurement themselves.
 * Also changed the destroy method so that it only does the destroy if it's a DELETE request, otherwise the destroy view is rendered.
 * Added a destroy view that contains a confirmation form.
The logout link click event should be withing the jQuery document ready event.
Oops, I'm pretty stupid for messing these up
Another round of putting ()'s around things. I *hope* this is all of them; I haven't found any more.
I missed putting ()'s around these two render calls.

Properly create measurement. I changed this in a previous commit and forgot that taken_on is protected. Guess I should remember to run tests
properly. I'll learn, hopefully!

Test updates.

 * Use _url instead of _path.

Test update.

 * Use _url instead of _path so that assert_select can match urls now that the views and controllers are using _url.
 * Removed two tests now that there is no edit action and the quantity cannot be changed manually.
The taken_on column can't be changed through mass assignment, so have to set it manually first before the other columns are updated.
There's no isdst column now. Only found that these were still in here from checking through the log file for the previous commits error and saw the mass-assignment warnings.

Fix the print_flash method. It broke when the hide a tag got put directly in the end string, and the use of 's in the a tag string (which was done using '''s) caused it to break and output the wrong html (ie. the # was making the string get closed and then the rest of the line was commented out). Thanks to the integration test html thingy for showing me there was an error, but it was mighty hard to find as it doesn't give any clue as to what test caused it. Went on a trip validating all of the pages (which needed a small number of fixes, I might add) and then ended up grep'ing the source files to find part of the string the html thingy was complaining about (cises.). That led me to the flash messages which I hadn't actually tried as it's harder to generate them in normal use. Had to fail a login to get one.

More markup changes.

 * Make the pages valid XHTML by removing the p tags around tables.
 * Also put divs (made inline with css) around the input tags in the forms.
 * Finally added a .total class that put the font-weight to bold, instead of adding b or strong tags.
Reformat the layout and remove the p tag.
Make sure there's a space before the selected attribute.

Some more changes, consisting of:

 * Converting _path to _url.
 * Putting ()'s around the render and redirect_to calls.
 * Formatting changes.
 * Some slight cleanup, like removing unnecessary begin and end lines when rescuing.

Quite a lot of changes, but generally all come under one of these:

 * Replaced _path with _url in routes.
 * Stopped using -%> in places where it's not needed (like in the middle of markup).
 * Layout changes to make the resulting html look a bit nicer.
 * Some simplification and reorganisation between files.
 * Renamed files to better reflect what they are, and to shorten the render calls in some cases.
 * Deleted files that aren't used any more or were just blank.
Give the login forms in the sidebar an id.

Meal test updates.

 * Extended the test to cover the new way of adding and removing foods on a meal.
 * Tidied up the test slightly by using the food calories instead of hard coded values.
Put a span tag around the quantity value.

More meal food item ajax work.

 * Allow the new meal food item form to be submitted via ajax, with it handling the creation,
   updating, and deleting of the food items and properly updating the quantity.
 * Added a bit more involved javascript click function so that the same function is used for
   handling creation and updating, sending the correct _method when updating.
Moved the food form out to a seperate partial, which is then rendered with the @foods collection.

Meals changes.

 * Changed the meal food adding form to allow changing the quantity and redirecting back to the same form instead of to the meal page.
 * Cleaned up the meal, food, and food item getting in the controller.
 * Made the quantity form buttons in the meal page submit via ajax.
Change the login page to not display the login boxes as they're already in the sidebar. Replace it with a short message telling the user to use the boxes on the right.
Also default sort by description as well as the name.
Have the default sorting be by name, not id.
Merge branch 'master' into meals-update
Convert the files from dos line endings to unix line endings.
Do a get request, not post, so that it matches up with how the calendar actually does it (plain hyperlinks).
Don't format the date when changing the calendar display date.
Set the display date to be the users 'today' date if it isn't set yet.
Again, the display date cannot be > than the users 'today' date, so we go back a year first.
The display date cannot be changed to > than the users 'today' date, so we have to go back a year instead.
The flash messages just have a standard class of 'flash' now.
Updated the test_helper file as the flash messages don't have seperate classes; they're all 'flash'.
Close the p tag.

Only render the food_item partial if it's an ajax request.

 * Redirect to the meal url if it's not an ajax request.
 * Tidied up the food item inc'ing and dec'ing a little so that there only needs to be one xhr check.
The destroy action should be login protected so that a logged out user can't see the logout page.

Add in the logout javascript code. Forgot that a plain GET link could be pre-fetched thus logging the user out.

 * Added a destroy.html.erb file that contains a simple form asking the user if they really want to continue logging out.

Allow the quantity of the food items to be changed via ajax.

 * Added a form to the quantity td of each food item with two image submit buttons,
   one for inc'ing and one for dec'ing the quantity.
 * Added a css file to remove the padding around the gorm in the quantity td's.
 * Added a js file that handles the ajax part of updating the quantity of the food items.
 * Added a new cross.gif file to be used as the real delete image, and changed the action
   back to actually destroying the food item instead of dec'ing the quantity.

Start of the meal update.

 * Moved the meal item tr out of the show template and into its own partial. This will be used later for updating via ajax.
 * Added a form and two images to the meal item partial. These are used for inc'ing and dec'ing the items quantity.
 * Wired up the controller so that the update action handles the inc'ing and dec'ing, and destroying the food item if the quantity is < 1.
 * Currently have the destroy action also dec the food item's quantity if it's > 1 and destroy if 1. This will change later on.

Renamed the meal_item partial to be just meal, as that is what it is (the meal_item name made me wonder what it was for at first). This means I can simplify the render call in the index action to just render a partial of meals, instead of looping through each meal.
Switch the logout link from a DELETE to a simple GET. This is more logical and it removes the need for the extra javascript to handle it, plus another page for people without javascript.
Removed the prototype related javascript files as it's now using jQuery.

Changed the logout link to be a normal link. The form creation and submitting is handled in a click event handler handled by jQuery. This makes the html neater and moves the js out to a seperate file. A standard html page will need to be added, for people with javascript turned off, which contains a form asking the user if they really want to logout, and that form does the POST.

Cleant up the flash handling.

 * Simplified the print_flash helper a bit as well as removing the prototype hiding stuff.
 * Added a function to the application.js file to hide any flash messages using jQuery.

More layout tidying.

 * Removed the javascript links for prototype and its effects files.
 * Added in jQuery and its UI file.
 * Included the authenticity token so that it can be used in other js files.

Tidying up the application layout.

 * Moved the javascript includes to the bottom of the layout file.
 * Seperated the stylesheet link tags to make the html tags line up in the resulting html.
 * Stuck ()'s around the stylesheet and javascript include tags, the renders and the yields.
Remove the commented out calendar includes as the calendar has been seperate for quite some time now.
Can use the new shorthand version of this now.
Doesn't need the 'new' here as it's in the title just above it.
There's no need to use '-%>' on lines that have other content on them, as it either doesn't do anything or messes up the line after it (the ones before the ul tags).
Give the users 'today' date a green background colour only if the display date isn't the users 'today' date (the css ordering means that the display date's class will take precedence).
Set the calendar date to the users 'today' date if the selected month is after the users 'today's month.
Set a new variable holding the users 'today' date, and use that for checking whether to link the days date or not, as @today changes to whatever day is currently selected.
Don't change the date to something that is after the users 'today' date.
Don't link the day number if the day is after 'today'.
Fix the typo in the default section name.
Don't link the month name if the month is after 'today's month.
Display the year after the month names.

Updated the tour pages.

 * The generate_thumbnails helper method now only takes the image filename. It's only for the tour images so the path can be hard coded. It also
doesn't need the align parameter as all of the images are now on the left.
 * There's a new div class, tour-p, that will put a 3px border above the div block to seperate it from the one above, except for the first one.
Updated tour images and added new ones.

Convert the generate_thumbnails.rb file from dos to unix line endings. Don't know why it suddenly stopped working with dos line endings as I haven't touched the file, or generated thumbnails, in ages.
Make the measurements part a bit nicer layout wise, and make sure that there is a space between the number and the '(' for the date.

Need to raise an exception here if nothing is found. It is currently only used when checking for a weight on a specific day to change the menu item, and the caching method that handles that already rescues from exceptions, so the exception raising is handled. The only reason for doing this is because nil.id seems to work differently in development than it does in production, with development causing an exception and production just generating a log warning.
The counts should be got from @date not @today, as @today will always be the current month, not the month that the user wants to navigate to.
Change it from cache_values to just cache_existing_weight in the weights model. The only value that really needs to be cached is the current dates weight to save a database call on every menu show.
Convert files from dos format line endings to linux line endings.

Only validate the uniqueness of the loginname if it's a new user (ie. just being created). This stops a uniqueness sql check being issued every time a user is saved (when they login).

Add indexes for the id columns of the tables. I don't really know if the underlying databases automatically index primary key columns, but it can't hurt (doing a .d in sqlite doesn't show a specific index, so if it does something then it's internal).

Made the calendar view issue far less select calls and thus make it a lot faster (from around 1.6s to around 350ms).

 * Changed the show action to get the counts for the items in the current month.

These methods do a lookup in their respective item hashes (passed to the method) to see if there are items for the passed day, and only do the link if there are items.
It's exercises-ball.gif, not exercise-ball.gif. Not sure when it got renamed, but I must have just not noticed it. ALso renamed the div to match the image filename.

Test to make sure the food item is updated if the food is updated.

Need to explicitly set the values to get the correct value.

Small changes.

Simplified the difference updating.

 * Use the ActiveRecord dirty stuff to check whether the location has changed and get the previous value from that, instead of
   storing the location value after the record is found. Clears up a tiny bit of memory as well as making it easier to read.
 * Only update the difference if the location or the measurement has changed. This means that we don't need to use a stop
   variable to control the difference updating as it won't continue unless it actually needs to.
